column1: Muskogee () is the eleventh-largest city in Oklahoma and the county seat of Muskogee County. Home to Bacone College
column2: it lies approximately 48 miles (77 km) southeast of Tulsa. The population of the city was 39

column1: French fur traders were believed to have established a temporary village near the future Muskogee in 1806
column2: but the first permanent European-American settlement was established in 1817 on the south bank of the Verdigris River

column1: After the passage of the Indian Removal Act of 1830 under President Andrew Jackson
column2: the Muscogee Creek Indians were one of the Five Civilized Tribes forced out of the American Southeast to Indian Territory. They were accompanied by their slaves to this area. The Indian Agency
column4: was built here in Muskogee. It was a site for meetings among the leaders of the Five Civilized Tribes.  Today it serves as a museum. At the top of what is known as Agency Hill
column5: it is within Honor Heights Park on the west side of Muskogee.

column2: the Missouri–Kansas–Texas Railroad was extended to the area. A federal court was established in Muskogee in 1889
column3: around the same time that Congress opened portions of Indian Territory to non-Native settlers via land rushes. The city was incorporated on March 19

column1: Ohio native Charles N. Haskell moved to the city in March 1901. He was instrumental in building on the land rush; he stimulated expansion of the city of more than 4
column2: 000 people to a center of business and industry by 1910
column3: with a population of more than 25
column4: 000 inhabitants. Haskell built the first five-story business block in Oklahoma Territory; he built and owned fourteen brick buildings in the city. Most importantly
column5: he organized and built most of the railroads running into the city
column6: which connected it to other markets and centers of population

column1: As Muskogee's economic and business importance grew
column2: so did its political power. In the years before the territory was admitted as a state
column3: the Five Civilized Tribes continued to work on alternatives to keep some independence from European Americans. They met together August 21
column4: 1905 to propose the State of Sequoyah
column5: to be controlled by Native Americans. They met in Muskogee to draft its constitution
column6: planning to have Muskogee serve as the State's capital. The proposal was vetoed by US President Theodore Roosevelt and mostly ignored by Congress; the proposed State of Sequoyah was never authorized. The US admitted the State of Oklahoma to the Union on November 16

column1: Muskogee lies in the Arkansas River Valley and has a low
column2: sea-level elevation compared to much of the rest of the state. The city is on the boundary of the oak and hickory forest region of eastern Oklahoma and the prairie
column3: Great Plains region of northeastern Oklahoma. It is a suburban community of Tulsa.The city's climate is considerably warmer and more humid than other parts of the state.

column3: is a soft spot for floods. In May 2019
column4: waters rose more than 42 feet on the Arkansas River. Those levels had not been reached since 1943 (although 1986 came close with water 39.6 feet high). The USS Batfish (SS-310) docked at the city's military harbor broke free on the river. Two barges filled with tons of phosphate broke loose and threatened to break the dam they were heading towards. Webber Falls was ordered to evacuate immediately.

column1: Muskogee is an economic center for eastern Oklahoma
column2: and is home to several industrial activities. Georgia-Pacific has a tissue
column3: paper towel and napkin manufacturing plant in Muskogee.  The 2.9 million square foot facility is Muskogee's largest employer with 800 workers.

column1: Muskogee is home to Honor Heights Park
column2: a World War I memorial park
column3: notable for its azaleas and the annual Azalea Festival held each April. During the winter
column4: people from across all 50 states travel to Muskogee to see Honor Heights transformed into the Garden of Lights
column5: a 132-acre (0.53 km2) Christmas lights display.

column1: Muskogee has six museums. The Five Civilized Tribes Museum preserves the art and culture of the Five Civilized Tribes. The U.S.S. Batfish and War Memorial Park's major attraction is the submarine USS Batfish. The Three Rivers Museum chronicles the history of the Three Rivers area and the railroads that helped create it. The Oklahoma Music Hall of Fame has been honoring Oklahoma musicians since 1997. The Thomas-Foreman Historic Home
column2: aka the Grant Foreman House is an 1898 farm house preserved with the furnishings of the Indian Territory Judge John R. Thomas and his daughter and son-in-law Grant and Carolyn Foreman
column3: Oklahoma historians and authors. The Ataloa Lodge is on the campus of Bacone College.

column1: At the center of Muskogee's flourishing arts scene is Muskogee Little Theatre (MLT). MLT was established in 1972 from the unused Sequoyah Elementary School. The theatre puts on up to eight shows per year including youth theatre
column4: and general community productions. The theatre is also committed to education and development arts programs including Youth Theatre camp
column5: voice lessons

column1: The City of Muskogee Foundation provides grants to community organizations and non-profit groups throughout the Muskogee community.The local paper
column3: was founded in February 1888 when Oklahoma was still a territory
column4: and continues to be published today.

column1: Muskogee is governed by a council–manager form of municipal government. The city manager is the administrative leader of the government and is appointed by the city council. The city's ceremonial head is the mayor
column3: at-large member of the council with limited administrative power.

column1: The city is divided into four wards
column2: with two members of the city council elected from each. Each member of the council is elected by the city as a whole but must reside in the ward he or she represents.  Elections are held on the first Tuesday in April in each even-numbered year. All elections are non-partisan; the mayor and the members of the city council receive no salary or compensation for their services.

column1: Muskogee is represented by two state representatives for House Districts 13 and 14. District 13 includes the west side of Muskogee while District 14 includes the east half of Muskogee. The city is represented in the state senate in Senate District 9
column2: which includes all of Muskogee County

column1: Both former Attorney General of Oklahoma Drew Edmondson and former Oklahoma Superintendent of Public Instruction Sandy Garrett are Muskogee natives.
The city is part of Oklahoma's 2nd congressional district. The city is also home to former U.S. Senator Tom Coburn.

column1: There are two primary public school districts in the city of Muskogee: Muskogee Public Schools
column2: which include the vast majority of the city limits and a large portion of Muskogee County

column2: Muskogee is the location of the Oklahoma School for the Blind
column3: a special institution for meeting the educational needs of blind and visually impaired students residing in the state of Oklahoma.

column1: Muskogee is home to four institutions of higher education: the public four-year Northeastern State University
column2: the public two-year Connors State College
column3: the public Indian Capital Technology Center and the private four-year Bacone College
column4: which is the oldest college in the state of Oklahoma.
